Guide to the Henry Walter Papers

                    <lb/>
                    <num>MS 3016</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Larry Weimer

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2018-02-02T15:48-0500</date>

extent.value: in 33 record cartons, 8 document boxes and 1 oversize folder

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: The Henry Walter papers primarily include Walter’s files as a speechwriter for New York City Comptroller (1970-1973) and Mayor (1974-1977) Abraham D. Beame. The files include drafts and final versions of speeches, messages to constituent groups, press releases, correspondence and memos, Beame’s daily public schedules, event invitations and related background briefing notes, and other documents concerning public relations activities in Beame’s office. The papers also include files related to Walter’s work as Press Secretary for Robert Morgenthau’s 1962 campaign for New York State governor and as the first Director of Public Information for the newly-formed New York City Department of Highways in 1963-1964. The papers also hold a broad range of New York City-oriented print matter, such as city government reports and local newsletters. Among these is a rich set of programs, seating charts and other documents ranging from 1956 to 2017 from the annual political parody show presented by the Inner Circle, an organization of New York City journalists and reporters.

p.value: In accordance with the conditions of the donation, Walter’s files concerning his work for Comptroller Harrison Goldin (Series II) are restricted at the present time.
This collection should be cited as the Henry Walter Papers, MS 3016, The New-York Historical Society.
The collection was donated by Henry Walter’s son, Paul A. Walter, in November 2015.

As Beame’s days in office came to a close, Walter transferred in November 1977 to work as a speechwriter for Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, a position he held until 1989 when Goldin left the Comptrollership after a failed effort to win that year’s mayoral election.

The collection also holds Walter’s files from his work from November 1977 to 1989 for Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, but those files are not currently open to research in accordance with the conditions of the collection’s donation.

subject.value: Controllership -- New York (State) -- New York -- Public relations

dsc.value:
Series I. Public Relations Files. Abraham D. Beame 22.92 Linear feet 1961-2000s (bulk, 1969-1977) Arrangement Note

The series is organized in two subseries:

Subseries I.A. Comptrollership Years 1961-1974 (bulk, 1969-1973)

Subseries II.B. Mayoralty Years 1960s-2000s (bulk, 1974-1977)

 Scope and Contents Note

The series includes Henry Walter’s files from his years as an assistant for public relations matters, especially in connection with speechwriting, for Comptroller (1970-1973) and Mayor (1974-1977) Abraham (Abe) D. Beame. The series generally includes three types of content: press releases from Beame’s office and other public statements made by Beame; working files underlying Walter’s public relations activities; and newspaper clippings. The working files include drafts and final versions of speeches/remarks, messages/greetings, daily press schedules, press releases, proclamations, briefing memos on appearances (e.g., other attendees, important background information, logistics), invitations for Beame to attend events and programs or other documents related to those events, internal memos, Walter’s timesheets and daily to-do lists, city government agency reports, and other materials related to Beame’s public appearances and communications. The subject matter primarily concerns city finances, politics, crime, drug abuse, and other such broad issues facing Beame, but also concerns specific events such as the celebration of the nation’s bicentennial in 1976 and the power outage/black-out of 1977.

The series also includes some documents, including original correspondence, from the 1960s primarily related to Beame’s positions on tax and revenue public policy matters, and some material from Beame’s post-mayoralty years.

 Subseries I.A. Comptrollership Years 8.75 Linear feet 1961-1974 (bulk, 1969-1973) Scope and Contents Note

The subseries primarily includes Henry Walter’s files from his years as Assistant to the Comptroller for Public Relations, from September 1970 to the end of Abraham (Abe) Beame’s tenure as Comptroller at December 31, 1973. The subseries generally includes three types of content: press releases from Beame’s office and other public statements made by Beame; working files underlying Walter’s public relations activities; and newspaper clippings. The subseries also includes some documents, including original correspondence, from the 1960s primarily related to Beame’s positions on tax and revenue public policy matters; these pre-date Walter’s involvement with Beame and likely were given to Walter in connection with his public relations responsibilities.

Press releases are found as four bound annual volumes for 1970-1973 and as unbound, foldered documents for the same years. The two sets appear to be largely identical. One important known exception is that the unbound documents include the press releases issued separately during Beame’s 1973 mayoral campaign and the transition period after his election. In addition to press releases, these documents include other forms of public relations material, such as speeches, remarks, messages, and the like. The sets each have “indexes,” which include a table of contents indicating date and subject matter of the documents. The bulk of the topics concern financial matters, such as bond sales, budgets, New York City's credit rating, governmental unit reorganizations and appointments, mass transit fares, expenses (e.g., Board of Education deficits, process for awarding management consultant contracts), and housing construction. Many of the topics, though financial in emphasis, have broader implications as well, such as drug addiction/drug abuse, the city's costs related to United Nations operations, home rule legislation in the state, proposed Manhattan House of Detention (Tombs) prison annex, and the Yankee Stadium renovation. There are also topics concerning national legislation (e.g., wage and price controls) and international matters, especially with respect to Israel (e.g., support for Soviet Jews, call for a UN investigation into Arab guerilla sabotage against people flying in and out of Israel, providing military jet planes to Israel, remarks at memorial services for the slain Israeli Olympic team members).

Working files include a mix of documents, including drafts of speeches and press releases (including unused material), Beame’s daily public schedules, carbon copies of outgoing correspondence over Beame’s or Walter’s signature, Walter’s to-do lists, notes, and time records, clippings, and reports issued by the Comptroller’s Office and other print matter, including the employee newsletter The Comptroller. One file includes the development of Beame’s mayoral candidacy announcement, with Walter’s observations on the events of that time (March 1973). Threaded throughout the files are glimpses of Walter himself, including carbon copies of short letters to his mother or to friends and professional colleagues. Most of these files are structured chronologically, with all matters from a given period of time (typically one month) filed together. A few files are subject-oriented and include correspondence, press releases, and other documents related to particular topics. These include a compendium of mayoral candidate Beame’s campaign promises and documents related to the efforts of one Abraham Broza to collect signatures on petitions in support of certain of Beame’s positions. These files also include Beame’s correspondence with state and city officials from the late 1960s, that is, prior to his comptrollership, concerning his positions on tax and revenue reform measures.

The files of clippings include mostly photocopies of articles from the New York Times, Daily News, Post, and other newspapers that concern Beame and New York City issues of interest to Walter as Beame’s public relations assistant. The files are especially extensive for 1973 and include the coverage of Beame’s mayoralty campaign.

 Arrangement Note

The subseries is arranged with the press releases first, followed by the work files, subject files, and clippings files.

 Separated Materials Note

Some print matter was removed from the collection to be cataloged and shelved individually in the Library collection. The catalog entries refer to the fact that they were originally part of the Henry Walter collection. Many of these removed reports were duplicates of those in the collection; among those removed without duplicates remaining were the Comptroller's Annual Reports for 1971-72 and 1972-73; the New York State Statistical Yearbook for 1972; the New York City Statistical Guide for 1964; and Comptroller's reports on the Phoenix House program (1970), middle-income housing program (1971), and Health and Hospitals Corporation (1971).

Includes the Comptroller's reports on New York City Off-Track Betting (OTB) Corporation and Investment Progress concerning the New York City Retirement Systems as of 30 June 1972.

 Working Files. 1973 February 7 9 1973 Scope and Contents Note

Includes the Comptroller's Office report concerning the condition of the Tax Deficiency Account and the Tax Appropriation and General Fund Stabilization Reserve Fund ("Rainy Day Account") in the proposed 1973-74 expense budget. Also includes a report prepared for the Comptroller on the South Bronx Model Cities Camping Program's activities at Shaker Village Work Group Camp in Pittsfield, Massachusetts.

 Working Files. 1973 March (3 folders) 7 10-12 1973 Working Files. 1973 March. Mayoral Candidacy Announcement 7 13 1965, 1973 Scope and Contents Note

Includes drafts of the announcement, Walter's notes on discussions planning the announcement (March 8) and other public relations matters for the campaign in March, Jimmy Breslin's age-related criticism of Beame's candidacy and drafts of the response, campaign handbills and pamphlets, and other matters from the first weeks of Beame's candidacy. Includes a transcript of NBC's Meet the Press broadcast of October 17, 1965, which included mayoral candidates Beame, William F. Buckley, Jr. and John V. Lindsay.

 Working Files. 1973 April (2 folders) 7 14-15 1973 Working Files. 1973 May 7 16 1973 Working Files. 1973 June 7 17 1973 Working Files. 1973 July 7 18 1973 Working Files. 1973 August 7 19 1973 Working Files. 1973 September 8 1 1973 Working Files. 1973 October 8 2 1973 Scope and Contents Note

Includes the October 1973 issue of the periodical The Young Democrat focusing on the upcoming election and the program for the New York Press Club's 25th Anniversary Byline Ball at the Hotel Roosevelt. Includes the Comptroller's report concerning the 1974-75 draft capital budget and the capital program for the five succeeding fiscal years.

 Working Files. 1973 November (3 folders) 8 3-5 1973 Scope and Contents Note

Includes an invitation to the Beame pre-election rally on November 4 and two photographs of Beame and his wife, likely at the election night celebration. Includes copies of "Managing New York City's Pension Funds," an undated presentation to the Legislature's Select Committee on Pensions by Third Deputy Comptroller Melvin N. Lechner.

 Working Files. 1973 December 8 6 1973 Scope and Contents Note

Includes the Comptroller's report Investment Progress concerning the New York City Retirement Systems as of 30 June 1973.

 Press Releases. Credit Ratings 8 7 1971-1973 Credit Rating Hearing Transcript 8 8 Circa 1972 Scope and Contents Note

Includes pages 74-132 of a transcript of a Congressional hearing concerning bond ratings.

 Abraham Broza Petitions 8 9 1972-1973 Scope and Contents Note

Includes correspondence and other documents related to Broza's efforts to garner public support for Beame's positions, primarily on the city's credit rating (1972) and the CUNY budget and the 35 cent transit fare (1973).

 Street Crime / Juvenile Delinquency 8 10 1973 Scope and Contents Note

Includes letters from Lou Shainmark, former Managing Editor of the Chicago Herald American, with proposals for reducing New York youth street crime.

 Youth Services Agency Expenses 8 11 1972-1973 Scope and Contents Note

Includes press releases, clippings and other documents concerning inquiries into the YSA's expenses.

 Press Releases. State-City Fiscal Commission 8 12 1970-1971 Scope and Contents Note

Includes two releases, 70-22 and 71-107.

 CUNY Faculty Appointment 8 13 1973 Scope and Contents Note

Includes correspondence concerning a dispute over a job offer of a professorship.

 Reconciliations of City Accounts 8 14 1972 Compendium of Beame's Campaign Proposals 8 15 1973-1974 Scope and Contents Note

Includes a compendium prepared by the campaign's Research Department, circa November 1973, and a version of Beame's mayoral inaugural address.

 Women's City Club Address / Commission on Status of Women 8 16 1973 October Housing in the Non-Urban Setting: An Initial Report on Problems and Programs 8 17 1973 Scope and Contents Note

Includes a paper sent to HUD by the West Virginia Housing Development Fund. The paper was forwarded to Walter by one of its co-authors, with a letter proposing national growth policy as a possible campaign theme for Beame.

 Time Records 8 18 1971-1972 Scope and Contents Note

Includes Walter's summary of his daily hours worked from mid-1971 to the end of 1972.

 Miscellaneous 8 19 Circa 1971-1973 Scope and Contents Note

Includes two portrait photographs, one of Beame and one of him with his wife; a parody letter from the Committee to Erect a Statue of John V. Lindsay; list of Comptroller's Office staff; draft of a letter from Beame to Robert Moses concerning Moses's proposal for Beame to be a member of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's committee on purchases and sales of art objects; clippings; and other items.

 Annual Report of the Comptroller of the City of New York for Fiscal Year 1970-1971 8 20 1971 October 31 First Mayoralty Campaign 28 1 1961, 1965 Scope and Contents Note

Includes a transcript of NBC's Meet the Press broadcast of October 17, 1965, which included mayoral candidates Beame, William F. Buckley, Jr. and John V. Lindsay; William F. Buckley Jr's announcement as mayoral candidate; Buckley's biography; and a New York Times Magazine article. Also an unrelated 1961 press release from Mayor Wagner's office.

 Presentation of the Reception Wing of Gracie Mansion 28 2 1966 September 27 Scope and Contents Note

Includes the booklet prepared by the Committee for Gracie Mansion, Inc. on the occasion of the presentation of the Reception Wing to the city.

 "Crisis in New York City's Finances: Causes and Cures" 28 3 1968 January 4 Scope and Contents Note

Includes the text of then-former Comptroller Beame's remarks at the Citizens Union and New School for Social Research.

 Revenue Reform Proposals 28 4 1969-1972 Scope and Contents Note

Includes correspondence and other documents concerning Comptroller candidate Beame's revenue proposals, especially for a joint state-city fiscal commission (1969, 1971); includes a letter from Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller (1969). Also includes correspondence with Mayor John V. Lindsay concerning a proposed executive branch reorganization, particularly with regard to "superagencies" (January 1970); letter to President Richard Nixon supporting a tax incentive program for employee training (January 1970); and an outline of remarks for the Midtown Council (October 5, 1972).

 Tax Reform (4 folders) 28 5-8 1969 Scope and Contents Note

Includes correspondence, analyses, statements, and other documents concerning Comptroller candidate Beame's various tax/revenue reform proposals, including those related to off-track betting (OTB), tax sharing, real estate tax exemptions, and others.

 Clippings. 1970 September-December 8 21 1970 Clippings. 1971 (2 folders) 8 22-23 1971 Clippings. 1972 (5 folders) 9 1-5 1972 Clippings. 1973 (8 of 20 folders) 9 6-13 1973 Clippings. 1973 (12 of 20 folders) 10 1-12 1973 Clippings. Undated 10 13 1971-1973 Subseries I.B. Mayoralty Years 14.17 Linear feet 1960s-2000s (bulk, 1974-1977) Arrangement Note

The subseries is arranged primarily in chronological order.

 Scope and Contents Note

The subseries of public relations files for the mayoralty years primarily includes Henry Walter's working materials as a speechwriter for Mayor Abraham Beame. The files include drafts and final versions of speeches/remarks, messages/greetings, daily press schedules, press releases, proclamations, briefing memos on appearances (e.g., other attendees, important background information, logistics), invitations for Beame to attend events and programs or other documents related to those events, executive orders, local law public hearing packages, clippings, internal memos, and other materials related to Beame’s public appearances and communications. Subject matter ranges from general issues facing Beame, such as crime, politics, and business/investment climate, to specific concerns of the time, such as the city’s fiscal crisis of 1975, celebration of the nation’s bicentennial in 1976, the city's hosting of the Democratic National Convention in 1976, and the power outage/black-out of 1977. Files from the early months of 1977, during which time Beame ran for re-election as Mayor, include some memos and summaries related to political campaign messaging, but generally there are no extensive campaign-issued documents here. Some files include reports and other print matter and these are noted at the folder level in the container list below. Indexes to speeches/remarks given by Beame are available in the files; these tend to emphasize the group to or occasion on which Beame spoke, not the subject matter. The subseries also holds a small amount of material, such as clippings and reunion plans, relating to Beame but dating from his post-mayoralty years.

 Beame Biographical 28 9 1960s-1970s Scope and Contents Note

Includes three photographs of Beame's inauguration as Mayor, biographical notes from the 1970s, and some published articles about Beame.

 Indexes 11 1 1974 Scope and Contents Note

Includes the alphabetical indexes (and some monthly chronological indexes) for Beame's remarks, statements, messages, articles, and the like during 1974. Press releases are not included in the indexes.

 Unused Speeches 11 2 1974 Personnel and Contact Phone Directories 11 3 1974 Mayoral Committee Lists 11 4 1974 Inauguration Documents 11 5 1973-1974 Scope and Contents Note

Includes program, invitation to inauguration and reception, standard portrait photograph of Beame, speech and drafts, and other documents.

Includes a selection of essays written by elementary and high school students on the subject "What I Want You to Know About New York City" for a New York Times contest; background materials from the Embassy of Spain concerning the visit of King Juan Carlos I and Queen Sophia, including two photographs of the royal family; and annual report for 1975 of the New York City Commission for the United Nations and for the Consular Corps, in connection with a 16 June 1976 speech by Beame.

Includes various materials in connection with events which Beame attended and delivered remarks: Salt Lake Mormon Tabernacle Choir information booklet and other Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints background material, including a photograph of President Spencer Wooley Kimball; lyrics to the new song "You'll Never Be Poor in New York" written by Ira Gassman, and performed at Gracie Mansion by the composer Jule Styne; Operation Sail 1976, International Naval Review and "July 4th 1976 in Old New York" brochures; Municipal Art Society award booklets for 1975 and 1976; invitation card to the Bicentennial ceremonies with Queen Elizabeth II (July 9); welcoming glossy brochure from the Citizens Committee for the Democratic National Convention to the arriving delegates (July 11); and the official commemorative program of the American Freedom Train.

 Press Releases. 1976 August 20 15 1976 Scope and Contents Note

Includes the Department of City Planning report Schools for Communities: Expanding the Use of Our Schools (in connection with press release 295-76).

 Working Files. 1976 August (2 folders) 20 16-17 1976 Transcript of Beame Examination before the Securities & Exchange Commission in the Matter of New York City Bonds 20 18 1976 September 1 Press Releases. 1976 September 21 1 1976 Working Files. 1976 September (4 folders) 21 2-5 1976 Scope and Contents Note

Includes a compendium of remarks in connection with proclamations granting honorary citizenships, 1975-1976; the report Recommendations for a Preliminary Community District Map from the Subcommittee on Coterminality of the Mayor's Charter Implementation Committee (Sept 20); a booklet issued by Lord & Taylor in connection with its 150th anniversary (Sept 22); and a photograph of Mr. Big Apple in connection with a Committee in the Public Interest autumn campaign (Sept 30).

Includes select Mayor Beame and Mrs. Beame speeches from October 1976; one audience, the Maritime Port Council of Greater New York & Vicinity includes both the 1976 and 1974 Beame speech.

 Working Files. 1976 October (5 folders) 21 8-12 1976 Scope and Contents Note

Includes documents related to the dedication of the Port Richmond Water Pollution Control Plant, including the mayoral letter and list of contents placed in a box in the cornerstone to be opened in 2026 (Oct 21); recommendations of Michael I. Sovern concerning negotiations between New York and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association (PBA) (Oct 21); brochures, including route map, for the first New York City Marathon (Oct 24); and seating list, program and other documents related to the New York Press Club's Byline Ball at which Beame was roasted (Oct 24).

 Series III. Public Relations Files. Other 1.17 Linear feet 1951-1993 (bulk, 1960s) Arrangement Note

The series is arranged by topic, in roughly chronological order.

 Scope and Contents Note

The series includes documents, much of which was prepared by Henry Walter, of a public relations nature for various public figures, other than Abraham Beame and Harrison Goldin. Most notably, these include Walter's files as Press Secretary for Robert M. Morgenthau during Morgenthau's campaign for Governor of New York in 1962. These files include press releases, speeches and remarks, drafts, correspondence, schedules, and campaign travel arrangements. The series also includes press releases issued by Walter in his capacity as the Director of Public Information for the newly-formed New York City Department of Highways (1963-64). Also from the 1960s is a folder of campaign brochures and other ephemera related to former reporter and Democratic candidate Martin J. Steadman's campaign for Congress from the 4th Congressional District (1966), with a letter from Steadman to Walter thanking him for his help and support during the campaign.

The series also includes a small amount of speechwriting done by Walter in the 1990s. These include drafts of remarks concerning retirement financial security by Cuyler Findlay of the AARP Investment Program at Scudder Investor Services (1991) and work Walter did for former Westchester County Executive Alfred DelBello, including drafts of a speech and an article on the international transboundary movement of hazardous waste (1990), business and jobs (1992), and for a public affairs program on Cablevision focused on crime and punishment (1993).

The series includes a small amount of miscellaneous documents concerning Walter himself, including his 1960 remarks to the Air Pollution Control Association on the topic "The Role of Public Media"; a guest pass to the 1964 New York State Democratic Convention; his 1970 resume; a letter leading to his hiring on to Comptroller Beame's staff; two family photographs; an "I Care" lapel pin; and other documents.

 Robert Morgenthau Campaign Files (12 folders) 29 1-12 1962 New York City Department of Highways Press Releases (5 folders) 25 5-9 1963-1964 Scope and Contents Note

Includes the first Annual Report of the Highways Department (issued January 2, 1964, for the year 1963).

 Martin J. Steadman Campaign 28 10 1966 Cuyler Findlay Speech 28 11 1991 Alfred B. DelBello. Waste Management (Projects 39 & 40) 25 10 Circa 1976, 1990 Scope and Contents Note

Includes circa 1976 campaign literature for DelBello's re-election as Westchester County Executive.

 Alfred B. DelBello. Business & Jobs 25 11 1992 Alfred B. DelBello. Crime & Punishment (2 folders) 25 12-13 1993 Henry Walter. Miscellaneous 28 12 1951-1970s Series IV. Inner Circle Show 0.83 Linear feet 1956-2017 Arrangement Note

The series is arranged in chronological order.

 Scope and Contents Note

Formed in 1922, the Inner Circle of New York Political Journalists (known commonly as the Inner Circle) is an organization of New York City political reporters and journalists that performs an annual amateur parody show lampooning city, state and national political figures. The show is a fundraiser for charity and has become a major event in which political figures, including the mayor of New York, now commonly perform. Henry Walter became a member in 1956, served as the organization's president in 1963, and performed in at least some of the shows. He also collected materials from the annual shows and those documents form this series.

The series includes the programs from the annual Inner Circle shows for every year from 1956 to 1999. For the 2000s, programs are missing from 2000, 2009, 2010, 2012, and 2013; the final year in the series collected by Walter is 2014. The programs include satirical cover art illustrating the theme of the year's show (which is often linked to a current pop cultural reference), the cast of characters and the performers, the lyrics to the show's many musical numbers, and reference to the commonly-recognized tune to which the lyrics were sung. For most years, the seating chart for the event is also included. The series also holds other documents for many of the years, including dress rehearsal programs (the dress rehearsal was held before the main event for members, family and friends), invitations/flyers (bearing the program's cover art), tickets to the dress rehearsal or President's reception, some scripts, and some miscellaneous documents, such as invitations to members to attend Inner Circle meetings.

The series also includes the program and seating chart for the 2017 show, the first to follow Walter's death in November 2016. The program includes a memorial statement for Walter on page 28 and a photo of him visiting the rehearsal on page 23 (4th row from top, 2nd from left).

 Inner Circle Documents (7 folders) 30 1-7 1956-1984 Inner Circle Documents (9 folders) 31 1-9 1985-2017 Series V. Print Matter 3.75 Linear feet in three boxes and 1 oversize folder 1950-2001 Arrangement Note

The series is arranged with the New York City directories first, followed by other print matter. The other print matter is arranged in the numerical sequence (1-255) of the items as found in the inventory provided by a member of Henry Walter’s family. This sequence is generally chronological, except that some oversize items from the 1980s are found at the end of the list. Copies of the detailed inventory are found in the two boxes that hold the other print matter.

 Scope and Contents Note

The series includes a diverse and idiosyncratic mix of printed materials dating from the 1950s to 2001, though mostly from the 1970s and 1980s. Very generally, the material concerns economic, political, cultural, and public policy matters. Most of the materials were created by New York City-based organizations, concern New York City matters, and seem targeted to a New York City audience, but some are of state-wide or national scope. The bulk of the series includes some form of periodical, especially newsletters, newspapers, magazines, and series of technical or policy reports. But with few exceptions there are no extended runs of any of the individual titles; most titles are represented by only a few issues, often only the first number of the title. Aside from periodicals, the series holds a variety of single issue documents of interest, such as commemorative booklets, souvenir programs, annual reports, calendars of events, publicity materials, and the like.

Newsletters perhaps form most of the series. These newsletters were created by government agencies, or groups within those agencies, for internal distribution or for the general public; public policy interest groups; political figures; commercial institutions; trade associations; and other organizations. There are also many small newspapers created for distribution within a specific New York City neighborhood, organization, or constituency.

A detailed list of the printed material was provided by the donor’s family and is housed with the documents. The container list below summarizes most of these items at the folder level.

In addition to these miscellaneous printed material the series also includes several New York City official directories, known as the “Green Book,” from the 1950s to the 1980s used by Henry Walter.
